questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician for the evaluation of severe nosebleeds and two episodes of bloody vomit over the past 40 minutes. He reports that he has had recurrent nosebleeds almost daily for the past 3 weeks. The nosebleeds last 30–40 minutes. He appears pale. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. The patient's upper body is elevated and his head tilted forward. The patient's nostrils are pinched for 15 minutes. Despite all measures, the nosebleed continues. Examination of the nose with a speculum does not show an anterior bleeding source. Anterior and posterior nasal packing fails to provide sufficient bleeding control. Endoscopic ligation of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Endoscopic ligation of the sphenopalatine artery is the recommended intervention in patients with posterior epistaxis that persists despite conservative treatment. The sphenopalatine artery, a terminal branch of the maxillary artery, is involved in most cases of posterior epistaxis.
Image Description:

The nasal septum is supplied by the following arteries:
- Anterior and posterior ethmoidal branches of the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery
- Sphenopalatine branch of the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery
- Superior labial branch of the facial artery (not shown here), which is also a branch of the external carotid artery

The Kiesselbach plexus is formed by the anastomoses between the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial arteries. It is located in the anteroinferior region of the nasal septum and is the most common site of epistaxis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although posterior epistaxis may originate from the posterior ethmoidal artery, this is a very rare scenario. This patient's epistaxis is most likely going to stop after ligation of a different blood vessel.

C) INCORRECT:

Although endoscopic ligation of the anterior ethmoidal artery is used for the treatment of epistaxis, it is only helpful in cases of anterior epistaxis refractory to conservative management. This patient's nosebleed is associated with hematemesis and there is no visible anterior bleeding source on examination of the nose, which suggests posterior rather than anterior bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic ligation of the lesser palatine artery would not treat this patient's epistaxis because this artery does not provide blood supply to the nasal cavity. The lesser palatine artery instead supplies the soft palate and tonsil.

E) INCORRECT:

The greater palatine artery provides blood supply to the hard palate as well as the anterior nasal septum and its ligation may be useful for treating refractory anterior epistaxis. However, this patient's nosebleed is associated with hematemesis and there is no visible anterior bleeding source on examination of the nose, which suggests posterior rather than anterior bleeding.
questions.hint: This patient has severe epistaxis and associated hematemesis while tilting his head forward (suggesting posterior bleeding) that continues despite nasal packing. The most appropriate next step in management would be to ligate a terminal branch of the maxillary artery.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of bleeding from his lips earlier that day. He has a history of recurrent nosebleeds since childhood. His father has a similar history of recurrent nosebleeds. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows multiple, small dilated capillaries over the lips, nose, and fingers. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HHT is not associated with an increased risk of glaucoma. Early-onset glaucoma is seen in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS). Affected patients also present with vascular anomalies, but they instead take the form of a port-wine stain (usually unilateral in the V1–V2 facial dermatomes) and vascular malformations of the choroid and CNS (e.g., leptomeningeal angioma, usually ipsilateral to the port-wine stain). SWS is not associated with telangiectasias or recurrent epistaxis.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk of hematological malignancies such as acute leukemia is not increased in HHT but in ataxia-telangiectasia (AT). Patients with AT usually develop oculocutaneous telangiectasias; epistaxis due to telangiectasias in the mucous membranes of the nose is rare with AT. Moreover, the earliest manifestations of AT are progressive cerebellar ataxia, ocular movement abnormalities, and other motor disorders (e.g., chorea, myoclonus); these neurological features precede the onset of telangiectasias by several years.

C) INCORRECT:

HHT is not associated with an increased risk of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL) and tuberous sclerosis (TS) have an increased risk of RCC. Neither VHL nor TS is associated with mucocutaneous telangiectasis. VHL is associated with mucocutaneous cavernous hemangiomas and hemangioblastomas of the retina or CNS. The mucocutaneous manifestations of TS are adenoma sebaceum, ash-leaf spots, Shagreen patch, and skin hamartomas.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with HHT are at increased risk of developing large arteriovenous shunts (especially pulmonary and hepatic), and subsequently high-output cardiac failure due to hyperdynamic circulation. Other complications associated with HHT include paradoxical emboli (emboli passing through a pulmonary arteriovenous shunt into the systemic circulation, bypassing the lungs) and anemia due to chronic gastrointestinal bleeding from telangiectasias in the gastrointestinal tract.

E) INCORRECT:

The risk of gastrointestinal polyps is the highest with hereditary polyposis syndromes (e.g., familial adenomatous polyposis, Gardner syndrome, Turcot syndrome, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, juvenile polyposis syndrome, Cowden syndrome). HHT is commonly associated with gastrointestinal telangiectasias but only rarely with gastrointestinal polyps (a subtype of HHT is associated with juvenile polyposis syndrome). A different complication of HHT is much more common.

F) INCORRECT:

HHT is not associated with an increased risk of pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytomas are seen in patients with multiple hereditary disorders, including multiple endocrine neoplasias types 2A and 2B (MEN 2A, MEN 2B), von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL), and neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). None of these conditions are associated with mucocutaneous telangiectasis. VHL is associated with mucocutaneous cavernous hemangiomas and hemangioblastomas of the retina or CNS. The cutaneous findings of NF1 are cutaneous neurofibromas, cafe-au-lait spots, and Lisch nodules. Patients with MEN 2B present with oral/intestinal neuromas and marfanoid habitus.
questions.hint: This patient's recurrent episodes of epistaxis and telangiectasias of the lips, nose, and fingers are consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), an autosomal dominant condition that is associated with vascular malformations.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl comes to the physician for evaluation of recurrent nosebleeds since childhood. She has multiple, small dilated capillaries on the lips, nose, and fingers on exam. Her father has a similar history of recurrent nosebleeds. Which of the following conditions is this patient at increased risk for?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The primary symptom of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is hematochezia due to bleeding from hamartomatous colonic polyps, rather than epistaxis due to telangiectasias as seen in this patient. Peutz-Jeghers also causes changes in bowel habits such as constipation or diarrhea, but this patient does not have any gastrointestinal symptoms. Finally, although most patients with Peutz-Jeghers have mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation on their lips, buccal mucosa, palms, and soles, they do not classically have true telangiectasias or arteriovenous malformations.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has recurrent episodes of epistaxis and telangiectasias of the lips, nose, and fingers, symptoms that are classic for hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome). Patients with this syndrome may also present with pulmonary or hepatic arteriovenous shunts, which may lead to high-output cardiac failure. Other complications associated with this syndrome include brain abscesses, stroke due to paradoxical emboli (emboli passing through a pulmonary arteriovenous shunt into systemic circulation, bypassing the lungs), and anemia due to chronic gastrointestinal bleeding from telangiectasias in the GI tract.
Image Description:

Telangiectasia of the tongue and lips are visible in this patient.

This is a typical finding in Osler-Weber-Rendu disease, a rare autosomal dominant genetic disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytomas are seen in multiple hereditary disorders, including multiple endocrine neoplasias types 2A and 2B (MEN 2A, MEN 2B), von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL), and neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). The cutaneous findings of NF1 are cutaneous neurofibromas, cafe-au-lait spots, and Lisch nodules. Patients with MEN 2A present with medullary thyroid cancer and parathyroid hyperplasia, while MEN 2B causes medullary thyroid cancer, oral/intestinal neuromas, and marfanoid habitus. VHL also presents with hemangioblastomas of the retina or CNS, as well as renal/pancreatic cysts. Furthermore, they are at an increased risk for renal cell carcinoma. None of these conditions are associated with mucocutaneous vascular malformations or epistaxis.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased immunocompetence with increased susceptibility to infections and likelihood of lymphoma and leukemia are seen in patients with ataxia-telangiectasia (AT). This condition can also cause telangiectasias of the face, as seen in this patient, but these are usually on the skin or conjunctivae rather than the lips or mucous membranes of the nose (leading to epistaxis). In addition, progressive cerebellar ataxia is a hallmark symptom of AT that this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Early-onset glaucoma is seen in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome. These patients also present with vascular anomalies, but they take the form of a port wine stain (usually unilateral in the V1–V2 facial dermatomes) and vascular malformations of the choroid and CNS (e.g., leptomeningeal angioma, usually ipsilateral to the port wine stain). The CNS vascular malformations lead to epilepsy, intellectual disability, and glaucoma due to increased intraorbital pressure. Sturge-Weber is not associated with telangiectasias or recurrent epistaxis.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL) have hemangioblastomas of the retina or CNS. These patients also have renal and pancreatic cysts, pheochromocytomas, and are at an increased risk for renal cell carcinoma. This patient does not have any of the symptoms associated with these conditions. In addition, facial telangiectasias and epistaxis are not consistent with a diagnosis of VHL.
questions.hint: This autosomal dominant condition that is causing this patient's telangiectasias is associated with arteriovenous malformations.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency room because of one episode of hemoptysis. His pulse is 110/min. Physical examination shows pallor; there is blood in the oral cavity. Examination of the nasal cavity with a nasal speculum shows active bleeding from the posterior nasal cavity. Tamponade with a balloon catheter is attempted without success. The most appropriate next step in treatment is the ligation of a branch of which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Posterior epistaxis only rarely originates from the posterior ethmoidal artery, a branch of the ophthalmic artery; it is much more likely to originate from the branch of another artery.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudoaneurysmal epistaxis is an emergency condition that may involve the anterior cerebral artery. Often a sequela of severe head trauma, an anterior cerebral artery pseudoaneurysm can cause epistaxis by protruding into the posterior ethmoid sinus. However, pseudoaneurysmal epistaxis is very rare; furthermore, no history of head trauma is given in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

The septal branch of the superior labial artery, which branches from the facial artery, contributes to the blood supply of the anterior nose, and can therefore be the source of anterior epistaxis. Since this patient has posterior epistaxis, ligation of this artery would not be appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

The occipital artery arises from the external carotid artery and courses posterosuperiorly toward the occipital area. It does not contribute to the blood supply of the nose and plays no role in epistaxis. Ligation of this artery or any of its branches would therefore not be appropriate.

E) CORRECT:

The sphenopalatine artery, a terminal branch of the maxillary artery, is involved in most of the cases of posterior epistaxis. Endoscopic ligation of the sphenopalatine artery is the recommended intervention in patients with posterior epistaxis that persists despite conservative treatment.
Image Description:

The nasal septum is supplied by the following arteries:
- Anterior and posterior ethmoidal branches of the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery
- Sphenopalatine branch of the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery
- Superior labial branch of the facial artery (not shown here), which is also a branch of the external carotid artery

The Kiesselbach plexus is formed by the anastomoses between the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial arteries. It is located in the anteroinferior region of the nasal septum and is the most common site of epistaxis.
questions.hint: A different branch of this artery can cause an epidural hematoma when ruptured.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man reports a 6-month history of worsening dyspnea on exertion without cough, chest pain, or other systemic complaints. He has no seasonal allergies or sinus symptoms but does report intermittent epistaxis.
He is afebrile with heart rate of 86 beats per minute and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 90% while he is breathing ambient air, but it decreases to 84% on ambulation. His sinuses are nontender. His tonsils are normal in size and without exudate. There is a blanching vascular lesion, 2 mm in diameter, on his right buccal mucosa. His lungs are clear on auscultation, and his cardiac examination is normal, revealing no murmurs. He has no rashes or other skin lesions.
After initial chest radiography shows an abnormality, CT of the chest is performed (figure).
What is the most appropriate therapeutic step for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lung transplantation would not be an initial intervention and is not appropriate for a patient with a single AVM.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical pneumonectomy has been used to treat AVMs that are refractory to embolization, but resection is not first-line therapy, because it can affect the patient’s long-term respiratory function.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, an inherited autosomal dominant disease that often manifests in young adulthood. The most common symptom is epistaxis caused by telangiectasias of the nasal mucosa, but these characteristic telangiectasias can also occur on other mucocutaneous sites. In addition, patients are at risk for arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) and cerebral aneurysms.

Pulmonary AVMs often result in exertional desaturation as the shunt physiological changes become more pronounced with increased cardiac output and flow through the AVM. These lesions also increase the risk for stroke, cerebral abscess, and hemoptysis. Pulmonary AVMs are readily identified on chest CT, as seen in this image showing an AVM in the right middle lobe (hazy, rounded opacities tracking along the vascular bundle).

Widely accepted indications for treatment include symptomatic hypoxemia, paradoxical embolization, and progressive enlargement. The preferred treatment is catheter-directed embolization. Expert guidelines recommend embolization for any pulmonary AVM with a feeding artery ≥3 mm in diameter, although embolization is increasingly recommended even for smaller lesions.

Key learning point: A patient with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, hypoxemia, and pulmonary arteriovenous malformation should be treated with catheter-directed embolization of the malformation.

D) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic therapies such as estrogen-based hormonal treatment (e.g., with ethinylestradiol and norethisterone) and bevacizumab (an angiogenesis inhibitor) have been used with some success to treat mucocutaneous telangiectasias in patients with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, but they do not have a role in managing hypoxemia secondary to pulmonary AVMs.

E) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic therapies such as estrogen-based hormonal treatment (e.g., with ethinylestradiol and norethisterone) and bevacizumab (an angiogenesis inhibitor) have been used with some success to treat mucocutaneous telangiectasias in patients with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, but they do not have a role in managing hypoxemia secondary to pulmonary AVMs.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of epistaxis that are intermittently severe. During the past year, he has had migraine headaches at least once a month. He also reports fatigue with dyspnea on exertion during the past several months. His father died at age 51 from a ruptured brain aneurysm.
The patient’s temperature is 37.5°C, his heart rate is 70 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Small red spots that blanche with mild pressure are noted on the buccal mucosa, tongue, and lips. He has subtle clubbing and cyanosis of the fingers. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
A neurologic examination is normal. Chest radiography is notable for a round, well-circumscribed mass, 2 cm in diameter, in the left lower lobe.
Laboratory evaluation reveals the following:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
8500
4500–11,000


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
70
80–100


Hemoglobin (mg/dL)
8.4
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
405,000
150,000–350,000



Ferritin (ng/mL)
10
30–300


What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is a clonal B-cell cancer that can manifest with anemia, recurrent epistaxis, and neurologic symptoms. This does not explain the pulmonary masses or the cyanosis and clubbing noted in this patient, however. The neurologic symptoms are typically headache and blurred vision, usually caused by hyperviscosity, an urgent indication for treatment. Neuropathy can also develop and is typically related to a paraprotein.

B) INCORRECT:

Eisenmenger syndrome could result in clubbing and cyanosis but would be ruled out because of the patient’s normal cardiac examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener’s) can manifest with pulmonary nodules and epistaxis; however, it is often accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fevers, weight loss, arthralgia, and malaise.

D) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not characterized by mucocutaneous telangiectasia and pulmonary hamartomas, but rather pigmented lesions and gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps.

E) CORRECT:

Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, also known as Osler-Weber -Rendu disease, is an autosomal dominant vascular disease. The vascular malformations are arteriovenous shunts, termed telangiectasias (if small) or arteriovenous malformations (if large). Clinical manifestations depend on the organ involved.

Four diagnostic criteria for hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia have been established: epistaxis; telangiectasias on the face, fingertips, or nasal and oral mucosa; family history of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia; and visceral lesions including gastrointestinal telangiectasias and pulmonary, cerebral, and spinal arteriovenous malformations and hepatic vascular malformations. Neurologic symptoms are attributable to the pulmonary or cerebral malformations. The disease appears to be related to mutations in the genes encoding endoglin, activin receptor-like kinase 1, and SMAD4.

The other diagnoses listed each have some characteristic of this patient’s clinical presentation but do not explain the entire constellation of symptoms.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with recurrent epistaxis, telangiectasia, and anemia is hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man presents to the emergency department with active left-sided epistaxis. He says that the episode started 2 hours ago and, when asked to estimate the amount of bleeding, he produces a hand towel saturated with blood. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and a mitral-valve replacement with a bioprosthetic valve 5 years ago. His medications include metoprolol and apixaban.
He is afebrile with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 98% while he is breathing ambient air. Examination reveals severe ongoing epistaxis from the left nares without a clearly identified source of bleeding; there is also blood visible in the posterior oropharynx.
In addition to fluid resuscitation, which one of the following management strategies should be undertaken next in this case?

choices.text: Perform an endonasal examination, and apply topical silver nitrate
Consult interventional radiology for embolization of the bleeding vessel
Place an anterior and a posterior nasal pack

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Silver nitrate cautery is effective only if the site of bleeding can be identified and directly cauterized for several minutes.

B) CORRECT:

Although this patient could have posterior bleeding, he is statistically most likely to have anterior bleeding, as more than 90% of epistaxis originates from the anterior nasal septum. Visible blood in the oropharynx does not necessarily indicate posterior bleeding. After fluid resuscitation, the next step in managing severe active epistaxis should be placement of an anterior nasal pack. When the bleeding is too severe to permit a sufficient endonasal examination to identify the source, stopping the bleeding should be the immediate focus.

Placing an anterior pack alone is preferred over placing both an anterior and a posterior pack because it is easier and associated with less risk of damaging the nasal mucosa. If the anterior pack fails, then placement of a posterior pack can be considered. If conservative management does not significantly slow or stop the bleeding, an otolaryngology consult should be arranged (for possible operative intervention).

Key learning point: Management of an anticoagulated patient with severe acute epistaxis should begin with fluid resuscitation, followed by placement of an anterior nasal pack.

C) INCORRECT:

Interventional radiology with embolization of a bleeding vessel should be considered only if the packing fails and the bleeding parameters are normalized.

D) INCORRECT:

Andexanet alfa, a reversal agent for factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban and rivaroxaban, would be appropriate to manage bleeding in certain scenarios, typically if the bleeding is life-threatening or at a critical site (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage or posterior epistaxis) or if other measures to control the bleeding have failed. This patient’s bleeding does not appear to be life-threatening, and the anterior nares is not considered a critical site. Therefore, other measures to control the bleeding, such as a nasal pack, are most appropriate at this time, with consideration of andexanet alfa if those measures fail.

E) INCORRECT:

Placing an anterior pack alone is preferred over placing both an anterior and a posterior pack because it is easier and associated with less risk of damaging the nasal mucosa. If the anterior pack fails, then placement of a posterior pack can be considered.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting intermittent headaches for the past month that have worsened during the past 2 days. He describes the pain as a throbbing at the back of his head and rates the severity as 6/10. He has had no associated photophobia, phonophobia, nausea, or vomiting, and he reports no vision changes, gait disturbances, or focal weakness. He has no history of recent trauma, takes no prescribed medications, and has no evidence of substance use on urine drug testing. He has no history of migraines or headache disorder. A review of systems is significant only for intermittent unprovoked nosebleeds.
On physical examination, the patient has a blood pressure of 125/75 mm Hg, a regular heart rate of 115 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 37.1°C. He is alert and responsive. He is noted to have scattered, 2-mm, red macules and papules on his tongue, lips, and oral mucosa. His neurologic examination is nonfocal with symmetric pupils, reflexes 2+ bilaterally, and an unremarkable fundoscopic examination. Kernig and Brudzinski tests are negative.
CT of the head is ordered to further evaluate the persistent headaches and shows multiple arteriovenous malformations.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand disease, the most common inherited bleeding disorder worldwide, is due to a deficiency of von Willebrand factor. Nosebleeds and bleeding gums are the most common manifestations. Von Willebrand disease is not associated with AVMs.

B) INCORRECT:

Moyamoya disease is a rare condition characterized by progressive narrowing of the intracranial arteries, leading to ischemic strokes. It is not associated with arteriovenous malformations.

C) INCORRECT:

CREST syndrome is an autoimmune disorder manifesting with calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasias. The telangiectasias tend to occur on the face, hands, and mucous membranes and increase over time; they do not result in AVMs.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s head CT, performed because of persistent headaches, shows multiple arteriovenous malformations (AVMs). AVMs occur when arterioles join veins directly, bypassing the capillary bed, which results in increased intravascular pressure. They can be present in any part of the body but are most frequently seen on the skin and mucosal surfaces as telangiectasias or in the brain, liver, or lungs. AVMs may be asymptomatic or may manifest with a variety of signs and symptoms depending on their location and size. AVMs in the brain manifest with mass symptoms such as headaches, seizures, vertigo, or other neurologic symptoms; in this case, the AVMs could explain the patient’s headaches. On rare occasions, AVMs can also be associated with bleeding.

The combination of multiple intracerebral AVMs and recurrent nosebleeds in this patient raises concern for a genetic predisposition to AVMs. The most likely condition to cause multiple AVMs is hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome).

Key learning point: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia is an inherited autosomal dominant genetic disorder that is associated with arteriovenous malformations of the brain, skin, liver, and lungs.

E) INCORRECT:

Hereditary spherocytosis is a congenital hemolytic disorder resulting in sphere-shaped erythrocytes. It can be either autosomal dominant (the majority of cases) or autosomal recessive. The change in erythrocyte shape results in diminished compliance of the cell and ultimately degradation of the abnormally shaped cells by the spleen. Initial manifestations may include anemia, jaundice, or splenomegaly; however, mild cases are asymptomatic. AVMs are not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to your clinic because of bleeding from his lips earlier today. He has a history of recurrent nosebleeds since childhood. His father also has a history of recurrent nosebleeds. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. On examination, you observe multiple small dilated capillaries over the lips, nose, and fingers. The remainder of the examination is normal. This patient is at greatest risk for which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with HHT are at increased risk of developing large arteriovenous shunts (especially pulmonary and hepatic), and subsequently high-output cardiac failure due to hyperdynamic circulation. Other complications associated with HHT include paradoxical emboli (emboli passing through a pulmonary arteriovenous shunt into the systemic circulation, bypassing the lungs) and anemia due to chronic gastrointestinal bleeding from telangiectasias in the gastrointestinal tract.

Key learning point: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia increases the risk of high-output cardiac failure due to arteriovenous shunts, especially in the lungs and liver.

B) INCORRECT:

HHT is not associated with an increased risk of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL) and tuberous sclerosis (TS) have an increased risk of RCC. Neither VHL nor TS is associated with mucocutaneous telangiectasis. VHL is associated with mucocutaneous cavernous hemangiomas and hemangioblastomas of the retina or CNS. The mucocutaneous manifestations of TS are adenoma sebaceum, ash-leaf spots, Shagreen patch, and skin hamartomas.

C) INCORRECT:

HHT is not associated with an increased risk of glaucoma. Early-onset glaucoma is seen in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS). Affected patients also present with vascular anomalies, but they instead take the form of a port-wine stain (usually unilateral in the V1–V2 facial dermatomes) and vascular malformations of the choroid and CNS (e.g., leptomeningeal angioma, usually ipsilateral to the port-wine stain). SWS is not associated with telangiectasias or recurrent epistaxis.

D) INCORRECT:

The risk of hematological malignancies such as acute leukemia is not increased in HHT but in ataxia-telangiectasia (AT). Patients with AT usually develop oculocutaneous telangiectasias; epistaxis due to telangiectasias in the mucous membranes of the nose is rare with AT. Moreover, the earliest manifestations of AT are progressive cerebellar ataxia, ocular movement abnormalities, and other motor disorders (e.g., chorea, myoclonus); these neurological features precede the onset of telangiectasias by several years.

E) INCORRECT:

The risk of gastrointestinal polyps is the highest with hereditary polyposis syndromes (e.g., familial adenomatous polyposis, Gardner syndrome, Turcot syndrome, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, juvenile polyposis syndrome, Cowden syndrome). HHT is commonly associated with gastrointestinal telangiectasias but only rarely with gastrointestinal polyps (a subtype of HHT is associated with juvenile polyposis syndrome). A different complication of HHT is much more common.
questions.hint: This patient's recurrent episodes of epistaxis and telangiectasias of the lips, nose, and fingers are consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), an autosomal dominant condition that is associated with vascular malformations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease presents with recurrent epistaxis over the past week. The current episode began 45 minutes ago. He takes lisinopril and aspirin daily. Vital signs are BP, 168/94; P, 88; oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination shows active bleeding from the left nostril with blood visible in the posterior oropharynx. After applying bilateral nasal pressure for 15 minutes, bleeding significantly decreases but does not completely stop. Anterior rhinoscopy shows ongoing oozing from the anteroinferior nasal septum. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Anterior nasal packing with nasal tampon
Posterior nasal packing with nasal balloon catheter
Immediate ENT consultation for endoscopic evaluation
Blood pressure control with antihypertensive medication
Topical vasoconstrictor followed by chemical cautery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasal packing is indicated when bleeding persists despite direct pressure and cautery attempts, or when the bleeding site cannot be identified. Because the bleeding source is identified and has partially responded to pressure, less invasive measures should be attempted before proceeding to packing.

B) INCORRECT:

Posterior packing is used for posterior epistaxis or when anterior measures are unsuccessful. This patient has anterior epistaxis from the anteroinferior septum, and the blood in the oropharynx is likely from the prolonged bleeding episode rather than indicating a posterior source.

C) INCORRECT:

Consultation with an ENT specialist is reserved for refractory bleeding despite local measures or when specialized procedures are needed. Initial management should be attempted first, especially because the bleeding site is identified.

D) INCORRECT:

While hypertension may worsen the severity of epistaxis, immediate blood pressure control is not the priority for active bleeding from an identified source. Local hemostatic measures should be performed first, and gradual blood pressure reduction can be considered after bleeding is controlled.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Despite this patient's hypertension and use of an antiplatelet agent, the bleeding site has been identified in the anterior nasal septum, and the bleeding has significantly decreased with direct pressure. Persistent oozing indicates that the bleeding site remains active and requires targeted treatment. The next step is to apply a topical vasoconstrictor, followed by chemical cautery to achieve definitive hemostasis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents with epistaxis that began 45 minutes ago. The patient applied direct pressure for 20 minutes without success. Vital signs are normal, and anterior rhinoscopy shows an actively bleeding vessel in the anteroinferior nasal septum. The patient takes warfarin with an INR of 2.8. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Topical vasoconstrictor followed by chemical cautery
Anterior nasal packing with ribbon gauze

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Topical vasoconstrictors followed by chemical cautery with silver nitrate is the most appropriate next step in management for anterior epistaxis with a visible bleeding site. The identification of the bleeding site allows for targeted cautery, making local hemostatic measures the preferred initial approach before considering systemic treatments or more invasive interventions.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior nasal packing is reserved for cases in which cautery fails or when the bleeding site cannot be identified. Since a specific bleeding vessel has been visualized, another step should be attempted first.

C) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulant reversal is considered for life-threatening epistaxis or when local measures fail. Initial management should focus on local hemostatic measures, and anticoagulant reversal requires specialist consultation due to this patient's underlying condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Otolaryngology consultation is reserved for bleeding that does not respond to local measures such as cautery and packing. Consultation at this stage is premature.

E) INCORRECT:

Posterior nasal balloon catheters are used for posterior epistaxis or when anterior packing fails. This patient has anterior epistaxis with a clearly identified bleeding site, making posterior packing inappropriate at this stage.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his father because of recurrent nosebleeds for the past week. Each episode lasts about 10 minutes and stops spontaneously. Today, he developed another nosebleed while at school and was sent home after the bleeding subsided. He has a history of seasonal allergies and uses intranasal corticosteroids. Family history is unremarkable. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He appears comfortable. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/62 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mildly erythematous nasal septum, and small crusts are present at the anterior-inferior portion of the septum. Dried blood is visible at the right anterior nostril. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Following examination, the patient's nose begins bleeding again. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Application of pressure to the nostrils

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasal cautery (i.e., chemical cautery with silver nitrate, electrocautery) is an effective treatment for clearly localized anterior epistaxis that persists despite initial conservative management. This method requires clear visualization of the bleeding site and is not the initial approach for episodes of uncomplicated anterior epistaxis due to the potential for tissue injury, infection, and septal necrosis, which can result in perforation.

B) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic anterior ethmoidal artery ligation targets a major artery supply to the nasal cavity and is reserved for refractory bleeding in anterior epistaxis. Ligation of the sphenopalatine artery is not indicated in patients with episodes of uncomplicated anterior epistaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior nasal packing (e.g., with ribbon gauze, nasal tampon) is indicated for ongoing bleeding in patients with persistent epistaxis after initial conservative measures have failed or if the bleeding site cannot be identified. Nasal packing is not the initial management for uncomplicated anterior epistaxis.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical vasoconstrictors (e.g., oxymetazoline) help manage nasal bleeding by promoting local vasoconstriction and reducing blood flow. While vasoconstrictors can be considered as part of the immediate management, especially in minor anterior epistaxis, they are usually not the initial step.

E) CORRECT:

Application of pressure to the nostrils is the initial step in the management of anterior epistaxis, particularly in hemodynamically stable patients with bleeding from the Kiesselbach plexus. Direct, uninterrupted, bilateral pressure for 15–20 minutes (e.g., by pinching the nasal ala against the nasal septum while the patient sits upright and leans forward to avoid blood aspiration) compresses the bleeding vessels and is typically sufficient to stop bleeding.
questions.hint: Episodic bleeding from the nostrils in a patient with a history of intranasal corticosteroid use and crusting at the Kiesselbach plexus suggests anterior epistaxis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a persistent nosebleed from his right nostril for the past hour. He reports the bleeding started after he sneezed forcefully. Application of firm, direct pressure to the cartilaginous part of his nose for 20 minutes has been unsuccessful. He has no history of bleeding disorders or recent facial trauma. His blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg, and his pulse is 95/min. Examination of the right naris shows a steady ooze of blood from the anterior nasal septum. There is no evidence of bleeding in the posterior pharynx. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical ligation of the sphenopalatine artery
Placement of an anterior nasal tampon

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a bleeding disorder could cause epistaxis, this patient has no personal or family history of coagulopathy, is not taking anticoagulants, and has a clear precipitating event. For an isolated episode of uncomplicated anterior epistaxis in an otherwise healthy young adult, routine coagulation studies are not indicated as an initial step.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical or endovascular arterial ligation is reserved for severe, refractory epistaxis that does not respond to more conservative measures. It is most often employed for posterior epistaxis. This patient has a simple anterior bleed and is hemodynamically stable, making such an invasive procedure inappropriate at this time.

C) CORRECT:

After initial conservative measures are unsuccessful, the next step in the management of anterior epistaxis is the application of a topical vasoconstrictor, such as oxymetazoline. This alpha-adrenergic agonist constricts the small vessels in the nasal mucosa, which can stop or slow the bleeding. Applying a vasoconstrictor also improves visualization of the bleeding site, a necessary prerequisite for potential chemical cautery if the bleeding persists. This patient is hemodynamically stable, making this minimally invasive intervention the most appropriate next step.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior nasal packing with a tampon or gauze is an effective method for controlling epistaxis by applying direct pressure to the bleeding site internally. However, it is a more invasive procedure that is typically reserved for cases in which bleeding continues despite conservative management. Since these less invasive measures have not yet been attempted, nasal packing is not the most appropriate next step.
questions.hint: This patient has an uncomplicated anterior epistaxis, likely from the Kiesselbach plexus, that has not responded to direct pressure.
